---
title: "Integration Guide"
---

This guide covers how to integrate simdcsv into your own projects using various build systems and configurations.

## CMake FetchContent (Recommended)

The simplest way to integrate simdcsv is using CMake's FetchContent module. This automatically downloads and builds simdcsv and its dependencies.

```cmake
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.14)
project(my_project)

include(FetchContent)

FetchContent_Declare(
  simdcsv
  GIT_REPOSITORY https://github.com/jimhester/simdcsv.git
  GIT_TAG main  # Or use a specific version tag
)

# Optional: Disable tests and benchmarks for faster builds
set(BUILD_TESTING OFF CACHE BOOL "" FORCE)
set(BUILD_BENCHMARKS OFF CACHE BOOL "" FORCE)

FetchContent_MakeAvailable(simdcsv)

add_executable(my_app main.cpp)
target_link_libraries(my_app PRIVATE simdcsv_lib)
```

This approach handles all dependencies (Google Highway for SIMD) automatically.

## Pre-built Static Library

To use simdcsv as a pre-built static library:

### 1. Build the Static Library

```bash
git clone https://github.com/jimhester/simdcsv.git
cd simdcsv

# Build static library only (no tests/benchmarks)
cmake -B build -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release \
      -DBUILD_TESTING=OFF \
      -DBUILD_BENCHMARKS=OFF
cmake --build build
```

This produces `build/libsimdcsv_lib.a` (or `simdcsv_lib.lib` on Windows).

### 2. Install Headers and Library

```bash
# Create installation directories
mkdir -p /usr/local/include/simdcsv
mkdir -p /usr/local/lib

# Copy headers
cp include/*.h /usr/local/include/simdcsv/

# Copy library
cp build/libsimdcsv_lib.a /usr/local/lib/
```

### 3. Link in Your Project

**CMake:**

```cmake
find_library(SIMDCSV_LIB simdcsv_lib PATHS /usr/local/lib)
find_package(hwy REQUIRED)  # Highway must also be installed

add_executable(my_app main.cpp)
target_include_directories(my_app PRIVATE /usr/local/include/simdcsv)
target_link_libraries(my_app PRIVATE ${SIMDCSV_LIB} hwy pthread)
```

**Manual compilation:**

```bash
g++ -std=c++17 -O3 -I/usr/local/include/simdcsv \
    main.cpp -o my_app \
    -L/usr/local/lib -lsimdcsv_lib -lhwy -lpthread
```

## Shared Library Build

To build simdcsv as a shared library (`.so`/`.dylib`/`.dll`):

### 1. Build the Shared Library

```bash
cmake -B build -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release \
      -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON \
      -DBUILD_TESTING=OFF \
      -DBUILD_BENCHMARKS=OFF
cmake --build build
```

This produces `build/libsimdcsv_lib.so` (Linux), `build/libsimdcsv_lib.dylib` (macOS), or `build/simdcsv_lib.dll` (Windows).

### 2. Install and Link

```bash
# Install (adjust path as needed)
cp build/libsimdcsv_lib.so /usr/local/lib/
ldconfig  # Linux only: update library cache
```

**CMake:**

```cmake
find_library(SIMDCSV_LIB simdcsv_lib PATHS /usr/local/lib)

add_executable(my_app main.cpp)
target_include_directories(my_app PRIVATE /usr/local/include/simdcsv)
target_link_libraries(my_app PRIVATE ${SIMDCSV_LIB})
```

## Embedding as a Subdirectory

If you want to include simdcsv directly in your project's source tree:

```
my_project/
├── CMakeLists.txt
├── src/
│   └── main.cpp
└── third_party/
    └── simdcsv/    # Clone or copy simdcsv here
```

```cmake
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.14)
project(my_project)

# Disable simdcsv extras
set(BUILD_TESTING OFF CACHE BOOL "" FORCE)
set(BUILD_BENCHMARKS OFF CACHE BOOL "" FORCE)

add_subdirectory(third_party/simdcsv)

add_executable(my_app src/main.cpp)
target_link_libraries(my_app PRIVATE simdcsv_lib)
```

## Minimal Example Project

Here's a complete minimal example that parses a CSV file:

**CMakeLists.txt:**

```cmake
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.14)
project(csv_example CXX)

set(CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD 17)
set(CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD_REQUIRED ON)

include(FetchContent)

FetchContent_Declare(
  simdcsv
  GIT_REPOSITORY https://github.com/jimhester/simdcsv.git
  GIT_TAG main
)
set(BUILD_TESTING OFF CACHE BOOL "" FORCE)
set(BUILD_BENCHMARKS OFF CACHE BOOL "" FORCE)
FetchContent_MakeAvailable(simdcsv)

add_executable(csv_example main.cpp)
target_link_libraries(csv_example PRIVATE simdcsv_lib pthread)
```

**main.cpp:**

```cpp
#include <simdcsv.h>
#include <iostream>

int main(int argc, char* argv[]) {
    if (argc < 2) {
        std::cerr << "Usage: " << argv[0] << " <file.csv>\n";
        return 1;
    }

    // Load CSV file with SIMD-aligned memory
    simdcsv::FileBuffer buffer = simdcsv::load_file(argv[1]);
    if (!buffer.valid()) {
        std::cerr << "Failed to load file\n";
        return 1;
    }

    // Create parser and error collector
    simdcsv::Parser parser(4);  // Use 4 threads
    simdcsv::ErrorCollector errors(simdcsv::ErrorMode::PERMISSIVE);

    // Parse with automatic dialect detection
    auto result = parser.parse_auto(buffer.data(), buffer.size(), errors);

    if (result.success()) {
        std::cout << "Parsed successfully!\n";
        std::cout << "Columns: " << result.num_columns() << "\n";
        std::cout << "Delimiter: '" << result.dialect.delimiter << "'\n";
        std::cout << "Total field indexes: " << result.total_indexes() << "\n";
    } else {
        std::cerr << "Parse failed\n";
    }

    if (errors.has_errors()) {
        std::cerr << errors.summary() << "\n";
    }

    return result.success() ? 0 : 1;
}
```

**Build and run:**

```bash
cmake -B build -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release
cmake --build build
./build/csv_example data.csv
```

## C API Usage

simdcsv also provides a C API for integration with C projects or other languages via FFI:

**c_example.c:**

```c
#include <simdcsv_c.h>
#include <stdio.h>

int main(int argc, char* argv[]) {
    if (argc < 2) {
        fprintf(stderr, "Usage: %s <file.csv>\n", argv[0]);
        return 1;
    }

    // Load file
    simdcsv_buffer_t* buffer = simdcsv_buffer_load_file(argv[1]);
    if (!buffer) {
        fprintf(stderr, "Failed to load file\n");
        return 1;
    }

    // Create parser components
    simdcsv_parser_t* parser = simdcsv_parser_create();
    simdcsv_error_collector_t* errors = simdcsv_error_collector_create(
        SIMDCSV_MODE_PERMISSIVE, 100);
    simdcsv_index_t* index = simdcsv_index_create(
        simdcsv_buffer_length(buffer),
        simdcsv_recommended_threads());

    // Auto-detect dialect and parse
    simdcsv_detection_result_t* detection = NULL;
    simdcsv_error_t err = simdcsv_parse_auto(
        parser, buffer, index, errors, &detection);

    if (err == SIMDCSV_OK && detection) {
        printf("Parsed successfully!\n");
        printf("Columns: %zu\n", simdcsv_detection_result_columns(detection));
        printf("Confidence: %.2f\n", simdcsv_detection_result_confidence(detection));
        printf("Has header: %s\n",
               simdcsv_detection_result_has_header(detection) ? "yes" : "no");
    } else {
        fprintf(stderr, "Parse failed: %s\n", simdcsv_error_string(err));
    }

    // Cleanup
    simdcsv_detection_result_destroy(detection);
    simdcsv_index_destroy(index);
    simdcsv_error_collector_destroy(errors);
    simdcsv_parser_destroy(parser);
    simdcsv_buffer_destroy(buffer);

    return (err == SIMDCSV_OK) ? 0 : 1;
}
```

## Linking Requirements

simdcsv requires the following when linking:

| Dependency | Notes |
|------------|-------|
| `pthread` | Required for multi-threading support (Linux/macOS) |
| `hwy` (Highway) | SIMD abstraction library (automatically included via FetchContent) |

When using FetchContent or add_subdirectory, these are handled automatically. For manual linking, ensure both libraries are available.

## Build Options Reference

simdcsv provides several CMake options to customize your build:

| Option | Default | Description |
|--------|---------|-------------|
| `BUILD_TESTING` | `ON` | Build test executables |
| `BUILD_BENCHMARKS` | `ON` | Build benchmark executables |
| `BUILD_SHARED_LIBS` | `OFF` | Build shared library instead of static |
| `ENABLE_COVERAGE` | `OFF` | Enable code coverage reporting |
| `SIMDCSV_ENABLE_ARROW` | `OFF` | Enable Apache Arrow output integration |
| `ENABLE_FUZZING` | `OFF` | Enable fuzz testing targets (requires Clang) |

For production use, disable tests and benchmarks for faster builds:

```bash
cmake -B build \
      -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release \
      -DBUILD_TESTING=OFF \
      -DBUILD_BENCHMARKS=OFF
```

## Platform Support

simdcsv supports the following platforms and SIMD instruction sets:

| Platform | Architecture | SIMD Support |
|----------|--------------|--------------|
| Linux | x86-64 | SSE4.2, AVX2 |
| Linux | ARM64 | NEON |
| macOS | x86-64 | SSE4.2, AVX2 |
| macOS | ARM64 (Apple Silicon) | NEON |

The library uses [Google Highway](https://github.com/google/highway) for portable SIMD abstraction, which automatically selects the best available instruction set at runtime.

## Compiler Requirements

- **C++ Standard:** C++17 or later
- **Compilers:** GCC 8+, Clang 7+, Apple Clang 11+
- **CMake:** 3.14 or later

## Troubleshooting

### "Highway not found" error

Ensure Highway is being built along with simdcsv. When using FetchContent, this happens automatically. For manual builds, install Highway first:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/google/highway.git
cd highway
cmake -B build -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release \
      -DHWY_ENABLE_TESTS=OFF \
      -DHWY_ENABLE_EXAMPLES=OFF
cmake --build build
sudo cmake --install build
```

### Linker errors with threading

Add `-lpthread` to your linker flags or `target_link_libraries(... pthread)` in CMake.

### SIMD instruction errors at runtime

This may indicate a CPU that doesn't support the compiled SIMD instructions. Highway handles this via runtime dispatch, but ensure you're using a Release build which enables proper optimization.

### Undefined symbols

Ensure all headers from `include/` are accessible and that you're linking against `simdcsv_lib` (not just `simdcsv`).
